issue.title: mitmproxy not throwing error on bad handshake

repository.name: mitmproxy
repository.description: An interactive TLS-capable intercepting HTTP proxy for penetration testers and software developers.

issue.body:
This may be more a netlib issue than mitmproxy, but I want to gather information about when a client doesn't like a self-signed cert or mismatched hostname.

The ssl connection for the client (and otherwise) looks to happen here:
netlib/tcp.py -> convert_to_ssl

I would assume on a bad handshake with the client (the client doesn't like the cert) an error is thrown in libmproxy/proxy/server.py at this call:

``` python
            self.client_conn.convert_to_ssl(
                cert, key,
                handle_sni=self.handle_sni,
                cipher_list=self.config.ciphers,
                dhparams=self.config.certstore.dhparams,
                ca_file=self.config.ca_file
            )
```

I believe that this function should be throwing an error based on netlib/test/test_tcp.py:

``` python
class TestServerCipherListError(test.ServerTestBase):
    handler = ClientCipherListHandler
    ssl = dict(
        cert = tutils.test_data.path("data/server.crt"),
        key = tutils.test_data.path("data/server.key"),
        request_client_cert = False,
        v3_only = False,
        cipher_list = 'bogus'
    )
    def test_echo(self):
        c = tcp.TCPClient(("127.0.0.1", self.port))
        c.connect()
        tutils.raises("handshake error", c.convert_to_ssl, sni="foo.com")
```

However this is not throwing any kind of exception.

I am running mitmproxy and netlib directly from master.  I am attempting to mitm an android application and know when the client (the app) rejects a self-signed cert.

In the event log has the following, but nothing about failed handshake:

```
192.168.1.212:58086: clientconnect
192.168.1.212:58086: error: NetLibDisconnect()
192.168.1.212:58086: clientdisconnect
```

body:
Hi Tyson,

If you use a reverse proxy specification starting with `https` mitmproxy assumes that both incoming and outgoing connections are HTTPS. To cover the ssl-terminating case, you can specify `http2https://example.com:80/` (or vice versa) as proxy specification. This is pretty fresh, still undocument and only available on the master branch, but it should work. :smiley: 

Cheers,
Max

Hi Max - 
I tried: -R httptohttps://www.gmail.com
which causes: 
127.0.0.1:49696: serverconnect
  -> www.gmail.com:80
127.0.0.1:49696: response
  -> HTTP/1.1 502 Connection refused

I also tried: -R httpstohttp://www.gmail.com
which causes:
127.0.0.1:49707: serverconnect
  -> www.gmail.com:80
127.0.0.1:49707: Establish SSL
  -> with client
  -> with server (sni: None)
127.0.0.1:49707: error: ProxyError(ProxyError(...), "SSL handshake error: [('SSL routines', 'SSL3_GET_RECORD', 'wrong version number')]")

It seems like something is not quite right still. 

This was running master from a couple hours ago.

Thanks
Tyson

Hi Tyson,

just to be sure - you tried `http2https`, not `httptohttps`, right?
Secondly, did you try to explicitly specify the port?

Cheers,
Max

Hi Max - 
You're right, I had a typo, but it also didn't work with http2https. 

using:
mitmproxy -p 9090 -e -v -v -v -v -v -R http2https://www.gmail.com
I get:
127.0.0.1:52532: clientconnect
127.0.0.1:52532: Set new server address: www.gmail.com:443
127.0.0.1:52532: serverconnect
  -> www.gmail.com:443
127.0.0.1:52532: Establish SSL
  -> with server (sni: None)
127.0.0.1:52532: request
  -> GET / HTTP/1.1
127.0.0.1:52532: response
  -> HTTP/1.1 404 Not Found
127.0.0.1:52532: error: NetLibDisconnect()
127.0.0.1:52532: serverdisconnect
  -> www.gmail.com:443
127.0.0.1:52532: clientdisconnect

This seems wrong, since I can get the expected response from curl -k -v https://www.gmail.com
(the result is a 301, but I assume this shouldn't matter?)

Thanks!
Tyson

Hi Tyson, looks like we definitely need to work on the documentation here. Strictly speaking, the feature is working as intended: 
> python mitmdump -d -R http2https://www.gmail.com/
127.0.0.1:50457: clientconnect
127.0.0.1 GET https://www.gmail.com/
    Host: localhost:8082
    User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.3; WOW64; rv:30.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/30.0
    Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,*/*;q=0.8
    Accept-Language: de,en-US;q=0.7,en;q=0.3
    Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
    Connection: keep-alive
 << 404 Not Found 1.39kB
    Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
    Content-Length: 1425
    Date: Tue, 08 Jul 2014 17:48:31 GMT
    Server: GFE/2.0
This behaviour is perfectly fine for a normal reverse proxy. However, your case is special as your proxy is not an "official/expected" reverse proxy - the `Host` header doesn't match the the upstream server's expectations. In other words, you need to override the Host header manually to get it working: `mitmdump -R http2https://www.gmail.com --setheader :~q:Host:www.gmail.com:` (see mitmproxy's [filter syntax](http://mitmproxy.org/doc/features/filters.html)) Note that this still doesn't catch HTTP redirects etc, which possibly redirect your client to the real machine (as it is the case with gmail). DNS spoofing or /etc/hosts would be the way to go then. Cheers, Max

- [x] Add http2https syntax to docs
- [x] explain the problems experienced here.

Hi Max - 
Thanks! 
This works, using --setheader. 

Thanks for all your help, again.

issue.title: SSL23_GET_CLIENT_HELLO

repository.name: mitmproxy
repository.description: An interactive TLS-capable intercepting HTTP proxy for penetration testers and software developers.

issue.body:
I run mitmproxy in reverse proxy mode
`./mitmproxy -R https://google.com -b 127.0.0.1  -vvv`
then
`lynx localhost:8080`

I have latest git snapshot of mitmproxy and netlib + latest pyopenssl/requests from pip. In fact I tried many other combinations of mitm and dependencies on a couple Ubuntu/Debian hosts.

To my surprise I just recently used this setup already and it had worked fine even on 10 version.

This is a mitmproxy eventlog: 

127.0.0.1:58327:clientconnect
127.0.0.1:58327: Set new server address: google.com:443
127.0.0.1:58327: serverconnect  -> google.com:443
127.0.0.1:58327: Establish SSL
  -> with client
  -> with server (sni: None)127.0.0.1:58327: error: NetLibError("SSL handshake error: [('SSL routines', 'SSL23_GET_CLIENT_HELLO', 'http request')]",)  
127.0.0.1:58327: serverdisconnect
  -> google.com:443
127.0.0.1:58327: clientdisconnect

issue.title: Is it possible to wildcard an https2http proxy?

repository.name: mitmproxy
repository.description: An interactive TLS-capable intercepting HTTP proxy for penetration testers and software developers.

issue.body:
Hi Max,

Would it be possible to do something like this:

```
mitmproxy -R https2http://\*:80
```

The idea would be that it would match all SSL traffic and redirect it to http, for multiple domains. The use would be for testing SSL when developing locally. Granted it works if the URL that is accessed in the browser is `https://localhost:8080` and the command is `mitmproxy -R https2http://localhost:80` - but my issue is that I have multiple local domain names setup in my `/etc/hosts` file.

Basically it throws this error:

> You attempted to reach `https://sandbox`, but instead you actually reached a server identifying itself as `https://localhost`

I checked out the [Reverse Proxy Documentation Issue](https://github.com/mitmproxy/mitmproxy/issues/304) and the [SSL23_GET_CLIENT_HELLO](https://github.com/mitmproxy/mitmproxy/issues/311) issues, and I realize that the `https2http` / `http2https` features are still undocumented but was still not able to figure this out.

I guess this could be the issue with the `CONNECT` before `REQUEST` way that the SSL handshake works? ... basically that the server name has to be specified via the command line since the hostname is not sent with the `CONNECT` ?

However, with the [Complication 3: Server Name Indication](http://mitmproxy.org/doc/howmitmproxy.html) it looks like there are some possible workarounds. Are they already built in or would this have to be something we would need to write?

Thanks!
